reviewText:
HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!! 9.5/10
I'll add more to this review later on

It's Borderlands 2 on steroids.

Pros over BL2 in no particular order:
-The vault hunters actually talk! One of the best aspects of the game now!!
-Wilhelm, Claptrop, and Jack's double make a reappearance as playable characters
-Low Gravity jet-packing fun. Slam your enemies in radius around you.
-LASER WEAPONS. There are so many types of lasers!
-CRYO WEAPONS. Freeze your enemies. No more slag!
-Inventory and stash space are MUCH better now
-Scenery is gorgeous and varied. Snow, lave, ice, space station, you name it.
-Elemental damage is viable end-game now!
-Skill trees are much more balanced. You get your special skill at level 3 now too!
-Loot scales much better. You don't have to replace your weapons every 2 levels anymore on the highest difficulty.
-Gold is actually useful now. Vendors have a chance of selling Legendaries (quite rare, but it happens)!.
-Item crafting! Repurpose your unwanted items for a new item with a good chance of getting a rarity upgrade. All the way up to legendaries (This costs 1-2 legendaries though, and it's not guaranteed)
-I like the music. The battle theme in the first boss area is so epic.

Negatives:
-Shorter game than BL2, but still loads of a replay value!
-Some of the missions (mostly side missions) can be rather tedious.

reviewText:
This is Borderlands, to the core, and a great credit to the franchise.
Low gravity combat, lasers, cryo effects, both new and re-imagined enemies, and a metric crap ton of that classic Borderlands humor we have come to love so much. Love the new characters, and ... you can play as Claptrap.

Did I mention humor?

I enjoy seeing the story leading up to BL2, and some of the side mission stories are cool as well. Seeing Jack be ... nice. The birth of the robot army. But, I will stop there, no spoliers.

As I write this, I see a small flood of spam in the reviews here on Steam, people hating on the game for various reasons. Everyone is most definitely entitled to their opinions, but a lot of what I am reading makes no sense. This is NOT a DLC or expansion, it's a full on game in it's own right.

People saying the humor is lacking, really? Have they actually played it? The humor is spot on for the BL series. Complaining that  some weapon designs and textures were the same as in BL2. Well of course it is, it takes place right before BL2.

People complaining about the $60 price tag, and while I am have been a long time critic of overpriced games, there is most defiantly $60 worth of game here. If you go for the full Borderlands experience, it's going to take you dozens of hours to complete, per character. Like all of the other BL games, we have coop as well. So I am not sure what people are complaining about.

Oh well, I guess some people just really like to complain. They hate it when you change something, they hate it when you leave it the same, sometimes you just can't win. Borderlands have become one of the largest, most popular, and most recognized franchises in the gaming industry. So it's expected to attract some hate.

Rest assured, it's unwarranted. If you truly enjoy Borderlands, then you will enjoy The Pre-Sequel.

OK, back to the game! =)

reviewText:
BL:TPS is basically Death by a thousand cuts.

This game is a strictly worse version of BL2. We surely expected a similar game, or even more of an expansion pack. Instead they've hybridized the worst parts of BL 1 and 2 into one fairly ♥♥♥♥♥♥ package. This is coming from someone with 500+ hours in 2, and currently sitting at 70 in this.

Pros first:
The low gravity combat is great, boosting/buttslams fit very well and just feel good to do. Melee specs play a mech-like dodge air game.

Playable characters all feel very different and have interesting skill trees/actions skills. More legendary drops while levelling.

Halloween event is neat and was rather unexpected.

Cons:

Low gravity isn't on in some areas, which makes you play a lot differently.

Dots received a huge damage buff, and lategame enemies have tons of lasers (high proc chance and dot damage), so you frequently find yourself dying a few seconds after the last enemy.

Area design is a lot worse. There are fewer areas and only one real hub (which is stacked deep with quests all throughout the game). Lots of backtracking through it, which isn't interesting or comparable to the progression in Bl2. Areas are more monochromatic and a lot less interesting to be in, much like in Bl1.

Droprate was buffed in vending machines and there is a horadric cube type random crafting system. Presumably to compensate, a lot of legendaries drop from one time encounters. This means you're faced with: Saving all quests with a unique mob until after you beat playthrough 2, making backups of your saves to farm them repeately, using backups to farm the grinder till you get what you want, or worst of all playing Vending Machine Farming Simulator 2015.

Non-respawning one time bosses: as mentioned above, more or less every unique mob encountered on a quest does not respawn, and they all seem to have unique head/skin drops or a legendary in their loot pool. This includes most sidequests as well as the first, and third to last story bosses.  This is a common complaint on both official forums, reddit, twitter, and in streams/from streamers or YT guys and has not been  acknowledged by 2k/2k Australia.

Tied into the above, the low number of quests. There are fewer sidequests than either previous game, and in order to maintain level parity in TVHM you have to do basically all of them. This sucks because it means either you don't save quest drops/farmables for 50, you grind mobs for hours to keep up, or you have fun being severely underlevelled. Especially near endgame the story quests jump ~4-5 levels in requirement and mob level, so you go from being 41-42 fighting lv 43-44 mobs to the last story quest being 48, with lv 49 mobs and a boss at 50. Its unforgiven and grindy due to how ineffectual personal healing is outside of using Moxxi's Probe.

Buggy launch: Based on Bl2s launch you had to expect some balance issues and bugs. TPS is a lot worse, and has some legitimately gamebreaking ones. People are having all equipment wiped from savefiles, any talented buffs are wiped by entering a vehicle, and random CTD is becoming a familiar friend.

Less pending DLC support: This applies more to people who bought the season pass after the strong support from Gearbox for Bl1/2. 2k has indicated the intent to release *one* campaign, s opposed to the 3/4 eleased for previous games. This may prove to be ill-founded or they may scale it up, but as it stands I already regret buying the season pass.

This last bit is subjective, but I feel the writing is a lot worse as well. It gets some cheap laughs by riding the jokes and NPCs from the previous games very directly, but offers almost nothing new or interesting. The decision to stick the story between the first two limited what they were able to do, and they did not excel within those constraints.

At the end of the day its an okay game, if a pale shadow of the predecessor. It feels like a cashgrab from the publisher (Gearbox was a consultant in development, but the game was made by 2k Australia and outsourced parts to several other studios). It is definitely not worth the full AAA title asking price. I'd pick it up on sale, and wouldn't buy the season pass unil they've released enough DLC to make it worth 30.

reviewText:
As much as I had hoped this wouldn't just feel like an overpriced DLC, that's exactly what it turned out to be.

I'd estimate that around 60% of everything you see during the game are reused assets from BL2.  Which boils down to the fact that they did half the work and want a full $60 for the game for just the base game.  Ammo venders reuse all of Marcus' lines from the previous game, all Hypyrion New-U stations reuse the lines from the previous game, there are a miniscule amount of new designs for weapons, and most textures are ripped directly from BL2.

It's of a respectable length.  I clocked in at 25 hours for my first playthrough with all side quests completed.

Story is rather lackluster.  Not particularly exciting.  The writing is below average.  While the humor was less handicapped than BL2 (The curse of Burch), it was mostly miss with only a few hits and laugh out loud moments.

The glitches are extensive and catastrophic in the first two weeks since launch.  They include having your entire inventory wiped randomly, leaving only your badass rank and level intact.  Some people suffer constant crashing.  Some people have their entire system restart.  Low gravity and poor collision detection cause loot to fly off the map or through walls.  Being hit with cryo weapons can cause you to become permanently slowed until you restart the game.  It's been two weeks and there is no patch in sight, and the hotfixes" have not fixed ANY of the aforementioned issues.

While the gameplay felt reasonable solid playing as Nisha or Athena
date: Wilhelm's action skill is strictly "release drones and let them fight for you" and Claptrap is broken and only of any use playing co-op.\n\nBottom line would have to be that I would have been content if it had released at $30
recommended: but at $60 it feels like a cash grab that wasn't as good as either of it's predecessors
hoursPlayed: and took half the work to make. It's worth playing but not at current cost.  Wait until a Game of the Year edition comes out.  In the meantime you're not missing enough to shell out full price."

reviewText:
I can honestly say, that the pre-sequel has the best gameplay out of all the Borderlands games. Some could argue that Borderlands 2 is the best game of the series and in a way they would be correct. Story and overall progression wise Borderlands 2 is better and the environment is more diverse. But Pre-sequel takes every aspect of Borderlands 2's gameplay and makes it better. For example the skill trees in Borderlands 2 are way more unoriginal and overall stale than in the Pre-sequel.

The loot drop rate is also handeld better. In Borderlands 2 I felt lucky if I found a blue loot and extremely lucky if I found a purple loot, and don't even get me started on legendary items. This issue is well solved in the Pre-sequel by making rare loot more common and with the introduction of the grinder. With the grinder you can grind loot you don't desire and get something more desirable.

Of course there are issues with Pre-sequel. First even though the pacing right at the begining of the game is better than any other, putting you in the middle of an invasion, the rest of the game is paced extremly poorly. There are times when I don't want to start new characters or start on a new game +, because the begining of the game is extremly tedious. Also Legendary farming is difficult with some loot due to the fact that they don't have a specific boss they drop from.

Overall The Pre-sequel beats Borderlands 2 in the gameplay section but otherwise Borderlands 2 is the better game. If you expect an epic story from this game you will be sorely disapointed, but should you just pick up this game with a friend and play it for the experience you wouldn't be dispointed. the game get's a solid 8/10. (also probably should wait for the game to go on sale, overall the games worth with ALL the DLC is about 40-50€)

I gave it a shot and wasn't all that impressed with it. I was excited for this game at first. Pros:

Cons:
Austrailian humor? Yeah sorry folks, a lot of the stereo-typed voice acting/jokes were a total turn off.

So it's totally okay for one character to just completely forget about part of their past in one game..then in this one they are demonized terribly and everyone seems to hate them now? Huge failure on the writing team. Good job making your storyline sound like it came from a bad fanfiction site.

Bottom line:

If you're still wanting to pick up this game, wait until there is better content and when it's on sale for like $25 or so, as it stands right now, it really is not a 60 dollar game, way too short, poor content and it left an ache in my already dark husk of a heart.

reviewText:
I can honestly say, that the pre-sequel has the best gameplay out of all the Borderlands games. Some could argue that Borderlands 2 is the best game of the series and in a way they would be correct. Story and overall progression wise Borderlands 2 is better and the environment is more diverse. But Pre-sequel takes every aspect of Borderlands 2's gameplay and makes it better. For example the skill trees in Borderlands 2 are way more unoriginal and overall stale than in the Pre-sequel.

The loot drop rate is also handeld better. In Borderlands 2 I felt lucky if I found a blue loot and extremely lucky if I found a purple loot, and don't even get me started on legendary items. This issue is well solved in the Pre-sequel by making rare loot more common and with the introduction of the grinder. With the grinder you can grind loot you don't desire and get something more desirable.

Of course there are issues with Pre-sequel. First even though the pacing right at the begining of the game is better than any other, putting you in the middle of an invasion, the rest of the game is paced extremly poorly. There are times when I don't want to start new characters or start on a new game +, because the begining of the game is extremly tedious. Also Legendary farming is difficult with some loot due to the fact that they don't have a specific boss they drop from.

Overall The Pre-sequel beats Borderlands 2 in the gameplay section but otherwise Borderlands 2 is the better game. If you expect an epic story from this game you will be sorely disapointed, but should you just pick up this game with a friend and play it for the experience you wouldn't be dispointed. the game get's a solid 8/10. (also probably should wait for the game to go on sale, overall the games worth with ALL the DLC is about 40-50€)

Okay, I've been putting off this review long enough- but there's definitely quite a lot I want to say.

I hear a lot of negativity about this game- saying it's the worst Borderlands game yet, that it should just be a DLC, and that it's not wroth any semblence of money- some people even claimed it was the worst Borderlands game of all time. Personally, I think the game is- in some ways- an improvement, and in others a step back. Let's start with the negatives.

The worst part of the game is certainly level designs (this is in the main game). Every level seems to be 'moon with large metal building' or 'moon with blue sky' and my personal favorite 'moon with purple sky'. Levels seem repetive, and variation doesn't exist. The Claptrap DLC, on the other hand, is fantastic when it comes to environments, having some of my favorite level design in any Borderlands game. So, I'm blaming Austrailia for this point (Sorry, mates.)

Second, the 'plot twists'. Though some of the plot twists were well handled, others seemed very AREN'T YOU SURPRIIIIISED! I know you're surprised, OH the plot twist. One of my personal favorite of these comes near the beginning (mild spoiler- go to the next paragraph if you don't want it) when you shut down the Jamming Signal on Elpis. You arrived, and go to talk to The Meriff. He avoids you, refusing to speak to you. He's very obviously part of the problem, as he stops you from leaving the town, and his speeches to the town are shifty at best. But then you learn (in Jack's worst performed line yet) that UGH! reviewText:
I can honestly say, that the pre-sequel has the best gameplay out of all the Borderlands games. Some could argue that Borderlands 2 is the best game of the series and in a way they would be correct. Story and overall progression wise Borderlands 2 is better and the environment is more diverse. But Pre-sequel takes every aspect of Borderlands 2's gameplay and makes it better. For example the skill trees in Borderlands 2 are way more unoriginal and overall stale than in the Pre-sequel.

The loot drop rate is also handeld better. In Borderlands 2 I felt lucky if I found a blue loot and extremely lucky if I found a purple loot, and don't even get me started on legendary items. This issue is well solved in the Pre-sequel by making rare loot more common and with the introduction of the grinder. With the grinder you can grind loot you don't desire and get something more desirable.

Of course there are issues with Pre-sequel. First even though the pacing right at the begining of the game is better than any other, putting you in the middle of an invasion, the rest of the game is paced extremly poorly. There are times when I don't want to start new characters or start on a new game +, because the begining of the game is extremly tedious. Also Legendary farming is difficult with some loot due to the fact that they don't have a specific boss they drop from.

Overall The Pre-sequel beats Borderlands 2 in the gameplay section but otherwise Borderlands 2 is the better game. If you expect an epic story from this game you will be sorely disapointed, but should you just pick up this game with a friend and play it for the experience you wouldn't be dispointed. the game get's a solid 8/10. (also probably should wait for the game to go on sale, overall the games worth with ALL the DLC is about 40-50€)

Okay, I've been putting off this review long enough- but there's definitely quite a lot I want to say.

I hear a lot of negativity about this game- saying it's the worst Borderlands game yet, that it should just be a DLC, and that it's not wroth any semblence of money- some people even claimed it was the worst Borderlands game of all time. Personally, I think the game is- in some ways- an improvement, and in others a step back. Let's start with the negatives.

The worst part of the game is certainly level designs (this is in the main game). Every level seems to be 'moon with large metal building' or 'moon with blue sky' and my personal favorite 'moon with purple sky'. Levels seem repetive, and variation doesn't exist. The Claptrap DLC, on the other hand, is fantastic when it comes to environments, having some of my favorite level design in any Borderlands game. I don't want to waste time, now then, to the point:

This is not the best Borderlands in any way, shape, or form. However, it's not so insanely horrible I would never reccommend it. But, I would recommend this game, if (AND ONLY IF) you have already played Borderlands 1 and 2 already.

reviewText: I personally found this game more enjoyable then Borderlands 2, and I put several hundred hours into that verison. While I feel that the replay value on this is a lot less, it's still too early to tell with the DLC coming if it will be more enjoyable. But in my opinion I feel as if the new features add a to the series and leave me with great hope IF a Borderlands 3 shows up! I thought the ice element was a great touch, and adds new level of combat with freezing and using explosive weapons to shatter. I personally am glad that the Eridian weapons are gone, because they were always the best and without then it adds the balance of weapons back from Borderlands 1. The Oxygen feature can be troublesome at first, but later on in the game you will find it doesn't play that much of a factor, and you can get some nice stat boost from the O2 kits themselves. Overall, if you are on the fence about getting the game I feel that I got my moneys worth, but I will add back to this with further assessments from the DLC to see how it changes things.

reviewText:
Only buy if you are a diehard fan of the series and have friends to play it with. For me playing this game has been a drag. Gameplay and mechanics are the same as BL2 and that doesn't bother me - BL2 gameplay was solid enough that it carries well into this game. But the pace, game length, loot system, and in general what was promised to us just didn't deliver. The Pre-Sequel has moved far and away from the space-western that was the first game and just feels smaller than the previous two games. BL2 was 25~ chapters compared to the Pre-Sequel of 17~. The majority of sidemissions are some variety of fetch quests. The new moon cast is largely fogetable, and there is the 'apperance' of Marcus (what, you couldn't come up with an alternate moon arms dealer?). The attempt to spice up the combat in the Pre-Sequel was done lazily - adding more bandits and monsters to fight doesn't change that the AI is terrible and predictable (the flow of combat came to the point where I could predict which cover the enemy would lock into and which side they would pop out of). Character dialogue is increased but its not streets ahead of BL2. An unimaginative end game raid boss. The list goes on. But my main gripe now comes with the latest DLC, Lady Hammerlock. Bear in mind its not her as a character I object to, its the fact that the 3rd DLC is another character class.

Track time, the first 3 DLC for each game:
BL1: Docter Ned's Zombie Island (expansion), Secret Armory of General Knoxx (expansion) Miss Moxxi's Arena (arena)
BL2: Mechromancer (character) Captain Scarlett and the pirates booty (expansion) Mr. Torgues Campaign of Carnage (expansion)
BL TPS: Handsome Jack (character) holodome Onsalught (arena) Lady Hammerlock (character)

Three DLC's in and the game hasn't gotten bigger, just the cast of characters.

The only thing I can guess that the Pre-Sequel did right is make the loot system not force you to keep swapping new guns every single level, allowing you to enjoy a gun for a handful of levels at least. It just feels as if the Pre-Sequel was handed off to a less capable team - sure they tried their best but their best wasn't good enough.

reviewText: Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel seems to improve on everything that was wrong with the first two games in the franchise in the gameplay department, but sacrifices the charm and comedic elements as well. Let's start out with gameplay. It is the same old Borderlands gameplay that you know and love, but with a new twist. On Pandora's moon, Elpis, there is low-gravity, which allows for new gameplay mechanics, that make the experience fresh and new. There are also new vehicles, which add for more diverse travels between different players. The game also runs fantastic, and look gorgeous. Some locations had beautiful settings with pitch perfect lighting, scenery, and even had lots of action going on with enemies, and still ran smoothly on my laptop. On the flip side, the game has several downsides. For one thing, the story falls short of my exoectations. If you have ever played a Borderlands game, you will laugh or chuckle at leasto nce every few minutes. In this installment, I only laughed 3 or 4 times, which was really a dissapointment. The story would have been acceptable if there were interesting characters, but there are very few. All in all, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is a great game for lovers of RPG's, Shoot Em Ups, or loot and farming games like Diablo.\nFINAL VERDICT   8.75/10\n

reviewText:
Borderlands pre-sequel was designed to fill in the details between BL and BL2.  Based on Elpis, the moon of Pandora, and Helios space station you meet Jack and discover how and why he changed into Handsome Jack. I thought the story was pretty good but depressing in some parts. Loved the Aussie accents and their little quirks and sayings which might explain why many people hate those parts of the mission. Loads of references to Aussie culture, like the snicket game, the swearing, the foul mouth gun Bognalla, janey Springs and her three words of wisdom, the swagman , Oz kits, the Dahl respawn station quotes, Red Belly and many more.

The gameplay is a lot easier than BL2 where tens of millions of damage were needed to defeat enemies. Cryo guns, and butt slams are so much better than slag but corrosive and fire less so understandably as there is little oxygen on the moon. Was possible to progress in the game with guns five levels below the mission level and a lot more legendaries from vendors.

However, some of the badass map achievements are mission related so fail to get it means you can not return unless you reset. Others only allow one person to complete the rank per day. At the moment only some of the DLC has been released and thats only been arenas which I am not fond of. And Jacks body double which I loved playing cause he did and said stuff I so wasnt expecting. Some of the boss fights are annoying too like DeadLift and his impossible Dead Weight badass achievement.

Can I recommend this? Definitely, but wait for a special and try and get BL 2 as well because then the pre sequel will make a lot more sense. Already spent over 350 hours here and will spend a few more as more stuff gets released.

Overall though, my biggest gripe with the game is what it has done to a couple of the well established goodly characters who at one point stand by and watch four peeps get murdered with barely a moan. This one just feels like a wonky wheel. It gets you there but it isn't as fun a ride.

reviewText:
After 2 playthroughs as Athena and now playing as Nisha, with 50+ hours in the game I'm finally ready to give the Pre-Sequel a positive review. I'm a huge Borderlands fan; BL 1 - Finished the GOTY edition multiple times on PC, PS3 & XBox, BL2 - 300+ hours spent mainly as Maya having purchased every conceivable peice of DLC available (yes even the headhunter packs). Therefore I had high expectations of the third entry in the franchise.

Upon first viewing it really does present as a re-skin of BL2, or as many have suggested, simply a substantial add on pack. The difference between BL2 and Pre-Sequel were nothing compared to the leap we saw in from first game to it's arguably superior sequel. As you progress through the campaign however, the apparent minor changes actually serve to present quite a different style of game. The low gravity combat and slower player movement is a huge change that drastically alters the pace of the gameplay, at least it feels like it does to players familiar with BL2 speed. Combine this with the unecessary O2 game mechanic and the initial impression is that 2K Australia took a wrong turn.

However, after persisting with this change I found it simply meant that I had to approach the game from a different angle and as soon as I stopped trying to play in the style of BL2 or even BL 1, I began to have a lot more fun. This is quite a different beast and the comments that it's too similar to the previous game are actually incorrect. It's vastly different in gameplay. The space setting on Elpis is a big change from the deserts of Pandora. The Australian accents play a big part in making this feel like a completely seperate environment. The new weapon and elemental types are a welcome addition that most people cited as a positive. The story, while not quite as engaging as BL2 is still interesting especially for people who've been invested in the universe from the beginning. The playable characters and their respective skills are arguably the most interesting and varied we've seen in the series and for the first time I feel a desire to try them all out. Overall, this is different than expected though utlimatley another satisfying entry to the franchise.

reviewText: Whether or not you should buy this game depends on a few things. I have to say upfront, that I enjoyed playing this game with my friends, but that probably has to do with the fact that I wasn’t expecting anything. A few of my friends that preordered and were really hyped absolutely hate this game with a fiery passion and will never touch it again. First, if you are big on story and characters, do NOT buy this game. The story and characters pale in comparison to BL2. To my memory, the game was advertised based on story and the game doesn’t really live up to that. When playing with my friends, the story seemed to be over way too quickly. If you are buying this game for gameplay, then there are both good and bad things. If you are buying NOW, the game finally has respawnable bosses fixing some of the end game stuff that the game lacked at first. It doesn’t totally fix it though and lots of end game stuff is still missing. I am no expert when it comes to that so go to a different review. What it adds for gameplay fits really well. Why haven’t we had double jumps, grinders, and lasers before? The gameplay is very close to borderlands 2. The enemies are not diverse in the slightest. In all, as a casual fan of the borderlands series who cares mostly about playing with friends, I enjoyed it. Know what you are getting into and buy it at a discount as there is not nearly enough gameplay as BL2 which was also $60. If you are looking for more borderlands 2 or to spice things up, look up Admiral Bahroo’s randomizer video on YouTube and try that first.

reviewText:
Technically, and design-wise, this game is better than Borderlands 2. Better jumping. Better guns. Better balancing. Better characters and abilities.

Where it fails... Is that there is less of it. Smaller maps, smaller levels, shorter missions, a story that is padded to hell... It's a great story, but the padding is very obvious.

See, Borderlands 2 had so much content that you could spend hours in it. Especially in bonus after game content.
The Pre-Sequel has none of that. Only one real expansion pack is out, and it's good. But it's only one expansion pack. The rest are characters and an arena mode.

You'll find a good game here, but after 2 playthroughs, I garuntee you'll have done everything the game has.

reviewText:
Let me first start off by saying I'm a huge Borderlands fan. I've got well over 100 hours into the first, and over 200 into the second.

So why do I feel conned when I play this one?

After 106 hours, I can safely say that this game starts slow and just never picks up. Thie environments are boring, the enemies are boring, the weapons are boring, the boss fights with the exception of the sentinel are boring. The only thing that's not quite so boring is the grinder, which spews out a legendary every so often. But then again, nearly all of the legendaries with the exception of the laser guns are ripped straight from Borderlands 2 so it just becomes boring again after that little sense of elation wears off when you find something orange.

On top of all this the DLC is all crap too.

I'll start with the character DLC which was graciously included by our 2K overlords in the season pass. Apparently this also affected the quality of both characters. The first was The Doppelganger Jack character who is a man named Timothy and through genetic modification, plastic surgery, and mechanical implants was transformed into a clone of Jack. Pretty solid backstory, but the scaling of this characters Action skill is overpowered. Not to mention there's a bug in Co-operative mode where if you cancel his skill before its halfway expended you'll get the whole thing back. That's right, 2k Austrailia ♥♥♥♥ed up so hard that they made an overpowered action skill and then accidentally made a bug that gave it no cooldown. What stand up gents.

Moving on, the next character is Lady Aurelia the Baroness. This woman is Sir Hammerlock's Sister.

Oh, you expected more? So did I.

This character seems like a quick slap together of something that resembles Mordecai and Claptrap. She's a sniper that has a action skill that flies around near your crosshair and attacks whatevers in the reticle. Sound familiar? Take the first S" off and you have Mordecai. The claptrap part extends to her third tree which is Co-operative only
date:
completely eliminating it as an option for single player characters. So you've got a rip-off character with a set in stone skill tree. Marvelous.

Onto the map and story dlc.

The Holodome

reviewText: Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel seems to improve on everything that was wrong with the first two games in the franchise in the gameplay department, but sacrifices the charm and comedic elements as well. Let's start out with gameplay. It is the same old Borderlands gameplay that you know and love, but with a new twist. On Pandora's moon, Elpis, there is low-gravity, which allows for new gameplay mechanics, that make the experience fresh and new. There are also new vehicles, which add for more diverse travels between different players. The game also runs fantastic, and look gorgeous. Some locations had beautiful settings with pitch perfect lighting, scenery, and even had lots of action going on with enemies, and still ran smoothly on my laptop. On the flip side, the game has several downsides. For one thing, the story falls short of my exoectations. If you have ever played a Borderlands game, you will laugh or chuckle at leasto nce every few minutes. In this installment, I only laughed 3 or 4 times, which was really a dissapointment. The story would have been acceptable if there were interesting characters, but there are very few. All in all, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is a great game for lovers of RPG's, Shoot Em Ups, or loot and farming games like Diablo.\nFINAL VERDICT   8.75/10\n

reviewText:
As of writing this I have played the game once as Wilhelm and I am about 50% in a claptrap playtrough.  (Normal mode.)

Overall this game is not as good as Borderlands 2. It is basically the same game with a few additions and a new story. It has its moments, but some issues holds it back. I would have given it a neutral rating if possible.

I would only recommend it to someone that have played and enjoyed Borderlands 2, and wants more.

Pros:

- Fun and surprisingly good classes. Nice that they speak this time around.

- The new lasers are fun.

- Cryo is a much better element than slag ever was.

- Lots of Dahl stuff to see.

- Neat bits of lore here and there.

Cons:

- Pandoras moon Elpis is not all that interesting compared to Pandora.

- This game have very poor map design in some places. Many maps are mazelike and cumbersome, filled with instadeath pitfalls.

- The new O2 mechanic. Whats the point in giving you a death timer like this? It adds nothing to the game at all, it just makes it stressfull. Why not just give players a jumpboost mechanic instead?

- Bosses are boring. From their bad and stiff intro to their boring fights. 50% of all bosses in the game is a big or small man in spacesuit with a buckethelmet.

- Everybody but you have jetpacks. They are hard to see and I want one too. And Kraggons. They never stop...

- The story in this game is understandably a bit darker than Borderlands 2, but sadly a bit of the charm was lost as well. Its not a masterpiece and sometimes dull.

- Many sidequests are extremly tiring. What seems like 2 objectives usually turn into 6 objectives. Some quests will have the player collecting very hard to get items, or do some sort of awkward hard maneuver to move on. Elemental weapons are often required and the game only assumes that you have that specific elemental weapon on you. They even put the exact same quest in there 2 times in different maps for some reason.

- The game is filled with australian references that non australians will not get. A few sidequests are just complete gibberish - like a billabong in a tuckerbag - ??

- To little innovation. The game is to similar to Borderlands 2, more should have been added. New loot, more guns, new enemies++.

- At the time of this rewiev, jan 2015, no decent dlc too speak off.

reviewText: You've explored enough of Pandora in Borderlands and Borderlands 2, so now, welcome to Elpis, Pandora's moon. Borderlands the Pre-Sequel is the third game in the series, and like its predecessors before it, is equally random and filled with craziness. The plot revolves Handsome Jack and his fall from hero to villain, along with new Vault Hunters that play minor roles in Borderlands 2 (considering the events of the pre-sequel happens before that). The story is engaging enough, and the Vault Hunters have a lot more lines of dialogue during quests, which is a nice addition and breathes more life into your characters. It is also quite amusing that all citizens on Elpis pretty much have an Australian accent, because the Pre-Sequel was developed by 2K Australia. Gameplay is enhanced with the introduction of the Oxygen system in the pre-sequel, considering you are on the moon, and you can now leap into the air and crash down on your foes in a low-gravity atmosphere. This is affectionately called butt-slamming" by the citizens of Elpis. This new Oxygen system also enables you to reach places that you otherwise wouldn't be able to

reviewText:
Of course the game does not live up to Borderlands 2, but once you create such a game like that it is impossible to live up to the hype created by the predecessor.

Admittably, the homey borderlands nostalgia does not strike as much as the second addition, the world feels a bit lacking, and a first playthrough left me feeling slightly offput. However after coming back to the game, i found myself quite happily playing through all over again.  To anyone who has played Borderlands 1 or 2, i strongly reccomend this game to you. Although it is a bit lacking in charisma, the gameplay is fabulous, and the enviroment is one of a kind.

Pros:                                      Cons:
-Gameplay is superb             -lacking in humor, and nostalgia
-Wonderful enviornment      -Not enough content
-Valuable storyline               -Bland NPC dialogue
-Unique expirience               -Not much good DLC produced
-polished features from bl2

Regardless of whether it seems like a let down, it is an enjoyable playthrough.

reviewText:
Borderlands 2 set a high bar for the series; it combined raunchy humor, infinite variable and fun weapons, multiple unique classes with three seperate specializations each, a lovable villain, fun and interesting characters, and a straightforward but complex story. Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel, unfortunately, did not live up to its predecessor. Much of the raunchy humor that made 2 and the 1's DLC so memorable is missing, the playable characters are bland (though still fun to play as), a forgettable villain, boring NPCs, and less of a story than slightly guided wandering.

However, much of the gameplay that makes the series so memorable is still there, and the game provides a backstory to the main villain and one of the side villains of Borderlands 2. It's still fun, the oxygen mechanic is interesting and useful, and the new laser weapon type can mimic every other weapon type, with its biggest advantages being the obscenely large amount of ammo and the extra damage when in oxygen. The Cryo element is also a welcome addition, as it is the first elemental type dedicated to something other than doing more damage.

Final Score: 7/10. Feel free to try it, but don't expect it to be as good as the last one.

reviewText:
Short Review:
A decent game with some cool additions from BL2. If you love Borderlands 2 - get it on a sale. If you have never played a Borderlands game get Borderlands 2 (GOTY). This game is for those people who want to know more about the Borderlands continuity. The story is no dissapointment!

Full Review: (BL2 Spoilers are ahead)
Story:
Now, I have started 2 main playthroughs of this game, the first when I first got the game and my second which I have just completed today. The game revolves around a time after the first game and before the second - as the name suggests. The game gets off to a good start with a decent cutscene lining up our 4 main vanilla characters: Nisha, Claptrap, Wilhelm and Athena. We meet Jack who is a low level Hyperion programmer wanting to find a vault which the lost legion (Dahl) wants to keep a secret.

The first mission is pretty decent in engaging us into the game. Then this is where the game gets really bad (for the meantime). Once you land on the moon, you are greeted by a beautiful yet barren landscape of Elpis. Janey Springs - a nearby engineer finds you and ends up asking you to do a few tasks for you until you get to Concordia - the Sanctuary of Elpis. You are met by Moxxi, Lilith, Roland, Earl, Nina (the doctor) and the Meriff. The story then progresses and starts to get a little bit better as time goes on. The next notably bad mission is the AI mission. Oh my is this a shambles. You arrive at this place seeking an AI to control a robot army or something (which was planned to assualt Helios). It becomes so stretched..... Go to this place, fight bandits........ Oh no, they have blown up the bridge....... Try to pour methane into the lava underneath to cool it.... Oh no, the methane has leaked; Go to a pumping station to fix this........ Oh no, the pumping station is not powered; find the power station........... and on and on and on. That I have to say felt like a low point in the story. Luckily, after that grind, things became a bit more interesting. There are a few anti climactic moments which I wont spoil and there are some amazing moments. I think the game really shines when you get off the moon and get back onto Helios.

Helios is really well designed; great colours, design, enemies etc. It was great and this was where missions started to pace a lot better. The ending and transformation of Jack is amazing and we can feel why he turned evil - it was the people around him. We see the Jack at the start who wanted to save lives and the Jack at the end who wants to end lives. Whats also cool is that we also see in the credits scene Wilhelm turning into a machine, Nisha getting Lynchwood and Claptrap getting his memory wiped and finds the BL2 Vault Hunters. That continuity for me was so cool to watch. The story was also good in the respect that it made me appreciate BL2 a bit more. For example: When Jack poisons Wilhelm so that he is actually killable to the vault hunters in BL2. This makes Jack a lot more a barbaric person. He was able to basically kill the person who had gone through so much with him. It just adds to Jack in so many ways and there are more of these little things.

Gameplay:
The core game mechanics are basically the same from BL2. The only differences I guess are O2 kits instead of Relics, Lasers as a new gun type, cryo as an additional element and slag being removed for continuity purposes (slag weaponry was not developed at this time in the Borderlands universe). There is now an oxygen mechanic which ties into the jump boost, slam and vaccum/breathable atmosphere concepts - all of which are new. This has changed gameplay enough to make it feel fresh but not too much as to make it feel not-borderlands. Oh and I think I forgot about low gravity jumping but it is self-explanatory to be fair. You could argue it slows down fights though; where enemies will be floating slowly around.

Also in terms of new creatures, there is not too many new and interesting enemy types and bosses can sometimes feel uninspired.

A lot of guns are borrowed from BL2 but I guess it is fine, there is enough new weapons to keep it fresh.

Graphics and Sound:
Most objects do come from BL2 but are retextured. The moon itself is quite beautiful yet barren, in the first few hours you will just be running around. To be fair, it has about the same level of detail in textures as BL2 with the same art style: I am not complaining!

Soundwise the game is fine, reusing alot of BL2 files. Marcus' vending machines for example use exactly the same clips from BL2. There is one main gripe though in terms of Science - sound does not travel in a vaccuum because there are no particles for it to travel through but whatever, it doesnt really matter. Voice acting is generally poor - for most of the inhabitants of the moon it sounds like the devs, 2K Australia, literally made the voices themselves. Most of the scav voices are horridly cliched, reused and unoriginal - the examples off the top of my head is Deadlift and those two bandit friends you meet in the story. Again this does not apply to all of them. The vault hunters, Moxxi, Jack, Lilith, Janey and all the other returning characters/voice actors are great - infact I enjoyed them quite alot.

Conclusion:
This game is driven by its story and specifically Jack. If you want more story and continuity to the Borderlands universe, get it on sale. If you want to check out Borderlands get Borderlands 2 and if you want more Borderlands 2, get it on sale. This game is good, but bad pacing brings it down in the first few hours. I do not believe this game is worth full price, with Borderlands 2 you will get more content and a more varied environment than in this game. In fact I didnt tell you about my two playthroughs, The first one I never completed, I just could never get past those few hours. The second playthrough, I forced myself to complete the story and I do not regret it, the last few story missions alone sell this game to me. If you disagree please in form me in the comments and we can have a constructive argument. Thanks for reading! (Damn that was long!)

reviewText: I've read a lot of detailed reviews that get many things right on the good side, but I have to disagree to some extent on the negativity.  The levels do seem boring at first and they are more boring than BL2 overall.  However, my biggest complaint was getting around early on.  The game takes awhile to offer you fast travel and vehicles to speed things up.  Well, BL2 did also, BUT the levels weren't so repetitive looking to start.  They do get better over time, but the first several levels of the Pre-Sequel are pretty boring.  Yes, the game is a hand-me-down and so one would expect more time on levels since there was less time needed to develop the game instead.  This is clearly a money/greed kind of issue (overpriced at $60, but probably worth it when on sale at $25-30) combined with a rush to get a sequel out faster.  However, at least the game is based on the totally awesome BL2 and less so on the original which I've started playing, but find it hard to get into due to point-of-view issues that can be hacked, but never truly fixed along with any kind of mini-map making it a PITA to navigate, horrible guns early on that are hard to easily compare, etc.  It's just painful to play, yet reading reviews on here that paint it as the second coming while the pre-sequel is total crap for not giving you farming farming farming farming BOREDOM action for the first 161 days, well... reviewText:
I'm just gonna compare this to the (quite wonderful) Borderlands 2, which this is otherwise extremely close to - figure out how you feel about that game first, then come back here. :)

Pros:
+ Somewhat better gameplay overall, mostly due to the jumpy/buttslammy stuff.  This is a big plus.
+ Player characters have a lot more character

Cons:
- The writing is a mixed bag, generally neither as funny or intriguing as BL2.  Some real face-palmingly misconceived lines.  But overall entirely adequate.
- Same engine, graphics, physics, menus; nothing technical has improved.
- Everything else about this game, from the level design to the audio, is a notch below BL2.  But that's okay, a notch below BL2 is still high.
- For people expecting to discover Handsome Jack's backstory and rise from zero to antihero: Mostly you don't.  Slightly spoilery details:  At the start of the story he's already a regular ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, he becomes a slightly bigger ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ at random points, and then at the end, bam, some deus ex machina makes him snap the other 90% of the way towards incredible ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ry.  No great arc giving him a good reason for his hate-on for bandits etc, nothing to do with Angel's mother's death which presumably happened before this game even started.

reviewText:
For all the hate and claims that this is just another BL2 I would tend to disagree and say this is a very fun game and can't wait for them to expand it out with the DLCs and various expansions.  By not being a DLC for BL2 they are able to dump some of the mechanics that didn’t work and get a fresh start without high level characters just blowing through it all.

A lot of the haters talk about it being not as long at BL2 as though that’s a bad thing.  I personally felt the main campaign in BL2 was too drawn out and made you do too much running around doing menial tasks to draw the story out.  When people talk about how awesome BL2 was they are looking at Tiny Tinas or Torgues or scarlets DLCs.  Just for reference I had all classes to 72 so I went through that painful storyline a LOT.

I felt TPS kept a better flow going and the missions weren’t stupid stuff meant to delay me.  Having it be its own game let it dump some of mechanics from BL2 such as Slag which caused all of the higher bosses to be balanced around its use and instead replaced it with Cryo which freezes things solid.

The campaign is about the same length or a bit longer than BL1.

New weapon type in the Laser, there are a couple of different laser types, the beam type which gradually become harder to hold on target, the railguns which are sorta like a mid range sniper and laser shotguns which aren’t really much different from regular shotguns.  Some of them can be useful but they aren’t earth shattering.
The butt slam can be a lot of fun,  I have buddies who will blast through areas just butt slamming everything that moves and giggling like little kids the whole time.

As for the classes they bring a different bag of tricks than the BL2 characters.  There is no one character who is completely overpowered like there was in BL2 (I’m looking at you Salvador).

There seems to be a bit more attention on characters benefiting each other than there was in BL2.  In BL2 there were only 6 skills that benefited teammates and like three times as many that a group oriented in TPS.

Very good game, and I look forward to what they come out with in the future DLCs

reviewText:
It's fun, but it's not Borderlands 2. Don't expect this to be as good as Borderlands 2...
It's a good game, just not a great game. I guess one of its main flaws is that its predecessor was a masterpiece.

The story is pretty bad for almost the entire game, but the ending makes up for it tho.
The level design is bad... like pretty bad... you might get pretty mad sometimes.

Vehicles are still buggy. Terrible and unimportant bosses in the game, with the exclusion of the last boss fight(s). Loot is pretty bad, but they made a new system: you get a GRINDER in which you combine 3 weapons (of the same quality) to get a better weapon.

The classes are very fun, it really feels like they invested a lot of time in developing their action skills and talents.
I'm afraid the characters don't have as much personality as the main characters did in the previous games.

I played the first Borderlands game for about 150 hours (PS3+PC), Borderlands 2 for about 260 hours (PC), I like this game series a lot, but I was as bit disappointed by BL:TPS.

7.0 - Play it if you enjoy the Borderlands universe and story. It could've been better, feels like they rushed the production...

reviewText:
It is a decent game. The campaign has a few laughs and the laser guns are a nice addition to the gun types in the series. The oxygen kits are frankly not all that different from the relics though. Some give you weapon damage, others give resistance, some give chance of free grenades. So I wouldn't call it a new feature. The low gravity adds a nice dynamic to the combat, since you now can reach higher places that you wouldn't on Pandora and have to worry about enemies hovering over you which were on ground a moment ago. The characters themselves are good to play with with and their skills are interesting. None of them especially feels overly powerful save for a few combinations and none of them feels weak (cough Axton BL2, cough). The scaling is better than BL2, at least at level 50 (can't tell about it once a level cap increase is released). So, your legendary gear won't go obsolete in 4-5 levels. Good defensive builds are actually viable at level 50, which feels good. The game is overall balanced decently in combat. The player characters also talk more, which is nice if you like more banter (I do). The legendary gear drop rates from enemies are still pretty bad (same as BL2), but the chances of finding legendaries in vendor machines has been increased, so money actually matters in this game if you want good gear and want to buy it when you see it in a machine. The other addition that really makes getting legendaries easier is the grinder, since you don't need to farm for a specific legendary. Just take whatever you got and you canuse the grinder to get a legendary weapon of a desired type (it still leaves some probability since there are many legandaries of a type, say sniper rifles, smgs, pistol etc., but still much better than farming one boss over and over and over).

The main complaint is that the campaign is really short. It feels shorter than BL2 campaign for sure, but it also feels shorter than BL1 campaign. You can complete main questline in 10 hours more or less on normal mode, WITHOUT speed running. Many of the side quests are poorly designed, which require to go to the same area over and over because you are not allowed to unlock all side quests at a place at once, for some reason (it was in BL2 as well, a bit, but here it is really bad). The maps are a bit unintuitive and most of them remind me of frostburn canyon from BL2, which was a bit tricky to memorize. The campaign also has a few plot holes and suffers from poor writing regarding how some of the character behaviors seem very forced.

Overall, I will recommend this game but not at full price. A price of $35-$40 sounds reasonable for a game of this length. And this is a definite buy for Borderlands series fans. So go on kiddos, buy this game (on sale, not full price) and make Jack happy. Learn how Jack turned from a somewhat ♥♥♥♥♥ to a complete psychopath in this game and shoot some bandits (oops, scavs) on the way!

reviewText: This game, unfortunately, is markedly inferior to Borderlands 1 and 2.  Despite using pretty much the same game engine and recycling much of the assets from Borderlands 2, the design of the enemies and levels just aren't at the same level of quality.  The combat rarely rewards careful tactics, instead often degenerating into disorderly brawls - not that this didn't exist in Borderlands 2, but in that game it was usually your choice how to engage the enemies.  Frequently, enemies don't spawn until you're in the middle of a room, then they spawn all around you, and the cover would be ineffective.  Maps are often confusing and lacking in distinctive landmarks.  Boss fights often take place in arenas that are awkward to maneouver or just entirely devoid of cover, again rapidly degenerating into clumsy brawls.  The story is irritating - you work for Handsome Jack, and he's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ - but that is more or less constrained by the story laid down in Borderland 1 and 2.  The humour is, well, Australian.  If you like it, you like it.  If you don't, it'll annoy you.  The one redeeming quality is the final boss fight, which is the only part of the game that, for me, felt like the quality I expect from a Borderlands game - the one part of the game that received the care and polish deserving of the Borderlands franchise.\n\nBasically, what I'm trying to say is, go play Borderlands 2 instead.

If you like Borderlands 2, This game is for you.
It has some improvement since Borderlands 2, that is, there is no slag.
In previous game, Slag was a elemental effect.
When enemy is under the effect of slag, the damage to that slagged enemy is increased.
It was powerful, that was the problem.

Under the presence of powerful slag, game was balanced for that.
The result, enemy's HP is so high which makes using slag almost mandatory.

Slag was powerful, but using the slag wasn't that fun.
You equip a weak damage but slag weapon just for slagging enemies,
then switch to high damage weapons to finish it off.
Borderlands has only 4 weapon shortcut slot, and switching weapons takes some times makes using slag stressful.

Since there is no slag in TPS, enemy's health is lower than B2.

The only things I don't like in TPS are just 4 weapon slots and switching weapons takes times.

reviewText:
Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel could be best described as a stand-alone expansion pack to Borderlands 2 more than a proper sequel. It acts as a prequel to the previous game, set between Borderlands and its sequel, and allows you to take control of four new vault hunters (Nisha, Athena, Wilhelm and Claptrap) as they follow the orders of an Hyperion executive, Jack, to stop an invasion on Elpis, Pandora's moon.
To state this as soon as possible, the Pre-Sequel! gameplay is strictly taken from Borderlands 2, so you may know already what are you in for: the formula is followed to the letter. The only four novelities this game brings to the table are zero atmosphere zones that foce you to manage your oxygen level, zero-gravity moves (extended jumps and a slam attack) and the cryo element (which takes over slag). Sadly enough, these new elements are barely as exploited in the Pre-Sequel! as they should be (oxygen management is a nuisance at best and aside from a couple of bosses you may as well fight with your feet on the ground the whole time). The laser weapons, if anything, really unbalance the game with some builds. So what you are getting with this title is a glorified Borderlands 2 DLC. To the game's credit, however, the new vault hunters have all unique abilities and playstyles and there are powerful endgame enemies to keep you on your toes.
It's also worth mentioning that the title isn't as rich in content as its predecessor (spotting far less areas, for instance), althought as the moment of this writing there are some planned DLCs that could help that.
Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel! is therefore mostly about his new characters and the whole Handsome Jack story arc, which pictures his slow fall into villany. If you enjoyed the Borderlands series up to this point, you should definetely give it a go. Else, you could as well wait for a proper Borderlands 3

reviewText: Whether or not you should buy this game depends on a few things. I have to say upfront, that I enjoyed playing this game with my friends, but that probably has to do with the fact that I wasn’t expecting anything. A few of my friends that preordered and were really hyped absolutely hate this game with a fiery passion and will never touch it again. First, if you are big on story and characters, do NOT buy this game. The story and characters pale in comparison to BL2. To my memory, the game was advertised based on story and the game doesn’t really live up to that. When playing with my friends, the story seemed to be over way too quickly. If you are buying this game for gameplay, then there are both good and bad things. If you are buying NOW, the game finally has respawnable bosses fixing some of the end game stuff that the game lacked at first. It doesn’t totally fix it though and lots of end game stuff is still missing. I am no expert when it comes to that so go to a different review. What it adds for gameplay fits really well. Why haven’t we had double jumps, grinders, and lasers before? The gameplay is very close to borderlands 2. The enemies are not diverse in the slightest. In all, as a casual fan of the borderlands series who cares mostly about playing with friends, I enjoyed it. Know what you are getting into and buy it at a discount as there is not nearly enough gameplay as BL2 which was also $60. If you are looking for more borderlands 2 or to spice things up, look up Admiral Bahroo’s randomizer video on YouTube and try that first.

reviewText:
So much negativity out there.

tl;dr: If you haven't played Borderlands 2 and/or cannot appreciate attention to detail, go back to playing CoD or whatever lackluster shooter you wile your life away with.

I loved the hell out of this game. Not so much because it's new and original and different from BL2, because in large part it isn't. In fact, it not being something completely new and original and different from BL2 was part of the hook. As far as gameplay, why fix what isn't broken? And hell, add some lazers and BUTT SLAMS. But as far as the story goes? Anybody who thinks it's lacking wasn't paying attention at some point in their Borderlands career. Likewise, it is NOT something you can just go and read about online if you want to catch the small details and nuances demonstrate how BL2 came to life. It isn't just about how Jack came to power; it's about how Jack stole the reins to Hyperion and flipped EVERYTHING upside down; it's a play-by-play of the deterioration of his humanity; it's a narrative of how his alliances and rivalries were forged; it's a testament to his ingenuity and how he used Hyperion to seize Pandora.

That said, it isn't a game to simply try to breeze through, shooting for the best loot. It's a novelty. A (Re)Making of Pandora" which you get to play a pivotal role in."

reviewText:
Technically, and design-wise, this game is better than Borderlands 2. Better jumping. Better guns. Better balancing. Better characters and abilities.

Where it fails... Is that there is less of it. Smaller maps, smaller levels, shorter missions, a story that is padded to hell... It's a great story, but the padding is very obvious.

See, Borderlands 2 had so much content that you could spend hours in it. Especially in bonus after game content.
The Pre-Sequel has none of that. Only one real expansion pack is out, and it's good. But it's only one expansion pack. The rest are characters and an arena mode.

You'll find a good game here, but after 2 playthroughs, I garuntee you'll have done everything the game has.

reviewText:
Oh hey, Borderlands 2 got an expansion. Wait, it's a full priced game? With it's own Season pass to boot!? Oh Gerabox you silly...

Now, based on that you ight think that I hate this game, but I don't. It's more Borderlands and I like Borderlands. All the stuff that worked before still work here. But the game adds nearly nothing into the Borderlands formula, except for zero-g jumping and (nearly pointless) oxygen tanks. The jumping is a great addition and I hope that they keep that in the future games, but besides that, I don't think this game does anything better than Borderlands 2.

I didn't find it to be quite as funny, except for a few missions. There are no stakes in the story because it's a prequel so you know what will happen.Most of the time they are merely filling in some blanks, or retconing the ♥♥♥♥ out of things. Also, Claptrap is able to go up stairs, which is simply wrong. The game is also far shorter than BL2. They did have a pretty nice variety of different locations, but even that pales in comparison to BL2.

This game is NOT worth a full price release. It should have been a 30€ at best. Gearbox is simply getting too greedy at this point. Still, even with all of it's faults, I did have a pretty good time playing through this game in co-op, so I am willing to give it a 6 out of 10. If you like the Borderlands game, you will most likely enjoy this one. If you don't, this game will do nothing to change your mind. I can't comment on the quality of the dlc's(those have been really good in the past) because I have not played them, and I'm not exactly eager to buy a season pass to something that propably should have been a standalone dlc in the first place!

reviewText:
What makes a good man? That is what ‘Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel’ asks of you in the last 10 minutes, as the avalanche of betrayals, heartbreak, and madness culminates in the creation of one of the finer video-game villains in the last few years. But, is he really the villain? He certainly believes himself to be the hero of this yarn. I guess, in the end, it is left to the Vault Hunter him or herself to decide upon the matter in a way they them self see fit. Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the prequel (and, of course, sequel) to one of the finest shooter games of last generation, and the origin of Handsome Jack.

Getting in to the meat of this look-back on this game, we shall start with game play. If you played Borderlands 2 (or the first Borderlands, for that matter) you already know the gist of how this game works and plays. You shoot enemies, you collect loot, and you kill more enemies. Subsequently, you also get more loot (and so on, and so on…). The Diablo-esque loot system was already refined in BL2, and did not require much in ways of improvement in TPS. The addition of laser-type guns is a fun one, and is a great addition to the stock experience. The beauty of what makes this system work is of course what every player loves-to-hate, RNG. Do you get a purple VLADOF sniper rifle that shoots corrosive bullets, all the while playing Mozart’s ‘Requiem’ in a solemn remembrance for the hundreds you have (and will) kill? Or do you receive a six shooter, which in a true Joker fashion doesn’t even shoot bullets? RNG at its finest.

The general game play, which is pretty much copy-and-paste from BL2, is enhanced by the addition of zero (almost) gravity. Jumping around has never been more delicious, and the fact that you can kill your enemies by butt-slamming on to them is just pure awesomeness. As fun as it is to just jump  up and down, all around, whilst breaking necks and taking names, the addition of platforming proves to be a two-edged sword. Whilst it does give a certain sense of exhilaration, going higher and higher, and exploring the countryside, when you get knocked back by an explosion or a ‘Lunatic’ (TPS’s Psycho) landing right next to you, or (as it happened many times to me) you just accidentally walk off of the edge, yer dead. And it’s back to the last save point for ya! This happened in such a rarity to me in early game that it didn’t prove to be more than an annoyance. But as the game progresses in to the late-game parts, especially in the purple-land-of-go-f***k-yourself, I could swear the developers were playing a practical joke on me.

The moon of Pandora, on which this game unfolds, is called Elpis. And hot-damn! How beautiful it is. As much as I loved BL2, one thing that always annoyed me (which was kind of bad, it being the most important part of it) was the world of Pandora. There just were too many browns, and reds, and just purely dull colors. Elpis, on the other hand, is a lot of…white. White ground, white walls, black sky. But look just over the horizon…and you’ll see some damn awesome backgrounds. The beauty of the space, mixed with all kinds of stuff that comes out of the ground, just makes the view very pleasing to the eye.

But, enough with that chatter. Let us enter the REAL meat of this review (and my favorite part of the whole game): the story, and characters. I personally hold these 4 Vault Hunters (Athena, Nisha, CL4P-TP, and Wilhelm) to be the best VH’s from the past 16. Maybe it’s the fact that we FINALLY get some interaction from them in regards to what happens in the story. Or maybe it’s how awesomely these 4 fit with the story of BL2. (*slight SPOILERS FOR BL2*) If you played BL2, you must remember Wilhelm, the slaughterer of New Haven, and someone, of whom even Angel was afraid of, and Nisha, the iron-fisted ruler and sheriff of Lynchwood, and Handsome Jacks’ girlfriend. They, of course, are one half of the VH quadruplet that saves Elpis. The second half is (oh god…) CL4P-TP (or Claptrap), and Athena. Claptrap you’ll know from the beginning, and entire game, of BL2, who heralds your ability to walk as being “…Handsome Jacks’ downfall!” And Athena actually comes from the first Borderlands, from the DLC ‘General Knoxx’s Secret Armoury’, as well as the EXCELLENT Tell-Tale’s ‘Tales from the Borderlands’ game (which actually happens after TPS).

To complement these excellent VH’s, you have Mad Moxxi (of course), Lilith and Roland, a new character called Janey Spring’s (who actually also appears in ‘Tales...’), and of course, Jack. I do not want to spill anything, but this game made me despise Lilith EVEN MORE than I already did, and made me love and feel sad for Jack (EVEN MORE than I already did).  Let’s just say that Lilith is kind of a (huge) ♥♥♥♥♥, who may have single handedly caused things that happened in BL2 to be as bad as they were. I actually rooted for Jack (duh, he’s one main characters) the entire game, and it this had been a completely ‘choose-your-self’ game, I would not have blinked a single eyelash before joining forces with Jack, and sticking a hot skewer through Lilith’s eye. But, alas, it is a fixed story, and I, playing as Athena, walked away from Jack, saddened that the man who was a Hero, who saved hundreds of people, descended in to madness.

Now, the final thing; the score. I personally loved the game, and I bet anyone who has had even a vested interest in BL2 will love, or like, this game as well. But for someone who is brand new to the franchise, Borderlands 2 is a much better starting point (even so than Borderlands 1). Though I loved the game, the last chapter of the game, which happens as you fight your way to a vault, was one of the most infuriating and skill-demanding levels in any game I have ever played. I, myself, play solo completely, and thus I had no help whatsoever as I faced a wave after wave of some of the most infuriating enemy types and mini-bosses. The level represents, in my honest opinion, a HUGE rise in difficulty. And it will be VERY infuriating. But, once you have finally gotten to the end, you can’t help but smile. ‘The Pre-Sequel’ is a great game, from a now defunct studio, and one that any self-deserving Borderlands fan should experience. 8.5/10

reviewText:
I will update this review as time goes by and as I progress through more characters and DLC launches etc.

Right, I have finished the game 4 times now, on 4 different characters, so I'll give out my final review:

THE PROS:
-Lasers. Borderlands does guns well, so it was no surprise that Lasers would be fun and easy to use. Athena can take full advantage of them, seeing as she rocks Elemental damage more.
-Character Classes. A big step-up from BL2, is how competitive each and every character can be. Nina was a solid choice for Beginners, whilst Claptrap allowed for some fun but still powerful builds. IMO Wilhelm has a lot going for him, and might be THE top dog.
-Vehicles. The new vehicles are a nice refreshment from the older ones in BL and BL2.
-Plot. The plot is thoroughly enjoyable. The ending was a really nice way to tie in the BL2 game chronologically, whilst still showing Athena's narrative of the events on the moon. Borderlands 3 anyone?

THE CONS:
-Voice Acting. You think giving everyone Australian accents is a good idea. It was. For 5 minutes. And then Pickle comes along and singlehandedly out-trumps Jar Jar Binks in annoyance levels. Even then, I wanted some really outlandish and crazy Ozzie to be used, but sadly, the enemies are duller than BL2.
-Orange Weapons+: As many have stated before, Orange Weapons are farmed by either Vending Machines, or by Grinding in a Grinder Machine. The chances of actually finding one from a dead boss is SLIM.
-Long Intervals of Play: Because you spend so much time in the air, in buildings, or just running to Oxegyn, you'll find yourself passing 5/6 minutes alone in getting to destinations. Coupled by how long it is before you get the first vehicle, the grind seems longer and longer. Not only that, missions usually set their completion areas a fair distance from them, prolonging the actual length of the game.
-Length. This game was originally planned as a big DLC for €30, and with the short story and limited interesting quests, you can see why. The only long bit of BLTPS is navigation. Fighting is fast paced and iconic of the older iterations.

So can I reccommend this? Not at €55. At that price point, I expect a solid 20+ hours of story and even more in optional side quests. Also, with the amount of DLC available for the game, BLTPS suddenly hits the €85+ mark.
But, if in a sale, like €30, then this game is well worth it, and longtime fans will feel their purchase was justified.

reviewText:
For all the hate and claims that this is just another BL2 I would tend to disagree and say this is a very fun game and can't wait for them to expand it out with the DLCs and various expansions.  By not being a DLC for BL2 they are able to dump some of the mechanics that didn’t work and get a fresh start without high level characters just blowing through it all.

A lot of the haters talk about it being not as long at BL2 as though that’s a bad thing.  I personally felt the main campaign in BL2 was too drawn out and made you do too much running around doing menial tasks to draw the story out.  When people talk about how awesome BL2 was they are looking at Tiny Tinas or Torgues or scarlets DLCs.  Just for reference I had all classes to 72 so I went through that painful storyline a LOT.

I felt TPS kept a better flow going and the missions weren’t stupid stuff meant to delay me.  Having it be its own game let it dump some of mechanics from BL2 such as Slag which caused all of the higher bosses to be balanced around its use and instead replaced it with Cryo which freezes things solid.

The campaign is about the same length or a bit longer than BL1.

New weapon type in the Laser, there are a couple of different laser types, the beam type which gradually become harder to hold on target, the railguns which are sorta like a mid range sniper and laser shotguns which aren’t really much different from regular shotguns.  Some of them can be useful but they aren’t earth shattering.
The butt slam can be a lot of fun,  I have buddies who will blast through areas just butt slamming everything that moves and giggling like little kids the whole time.

As for the classes they bring a different bag of tricks than the BL2 characters.  There is no one character who is completely overpowered like there was in BL2 (I’m looking at you Salvador).

There seems to be a bit more attention on characters benefiting each other than there was in BL2.  In BL2 there were only 6 skills that benefited teammates and like three times as many that a group oriented in TPS.

Very good game, and I look forward to what they come out with in the future DLCs

reviewText:
After 2 playthroughs as Athena and now playing as Nisha, with 50+ hours in the game I'm finally ready to give the Pre-Sequel a positive review. I'm a huge Borderlands fan; BL 1 - Finished the GOTY edition multiple times on PC, PS3 & XBox, BL2 - 300+ hours spent mainly as Maya having purchased every conceivable peice of DLC available (yes even the headhunter packs). Therefore I had high expectations of the third entry in the franchise.

Upon first viewing it really does present as a re-skin of BL2, or as many have suggested, simply a substantial add on pack. The difference between BL2 and Pre-Sequel were nothing compared to the leap we saw in from first game to it's arguably superior sequel. As you progress through the campaign however, the apparent minor changes actually serve to present quite a different style of game. The low gravity combat and slower player movement is a huge change that drastically alters the pace of the gameplay, at least it feels like it does to players familiar with BL2 speed. Combine this with the unecessary O2 game mechanic and the initial impression is that 2K Australia took a wrong turn.

However, after persisting with this change I found it simply meant that I had to approach the game from a different angle and as soon as I stopped trying to play in the style of BL2 or even BL 1, I began to have a lot more fun. This is quite a different beast and the comments that it's too similar to the previous game are actually incorrect. It's vastly different in gameplay. The space setting on Elpis is a big change from the deserts of Pandora. The Australian accents play a big part in making this feel like a completely seperate environment. The new weapon and elemental types are a welcome addition that most people cited as a positive. The story, while not quite as engaging as BL2 is still interesting especially for people who've been invested in the universe from the beginning. The playable characters and their respective skills are arguably the most interesting and varied we've seen in the series and for the first time I feel a desire to try them all out. Overall, this is different than expected though utlimatley another satisfying entry to the franchise.

reviewText: I have played Borderlands enough that I have become intimately familiar wih its various strengths and weaknesses as as series, and Pre-Sequel as a lot of both. An interquel that reuses the engine and assets of Borderlands 2, Pre-Sequel nonetheless manages to reinvent the series tried-and-true, shoot, loot, rinse and repeat gameplay primarily by the introduction of low gravity- moving around on Elpis and the Helios spacestation is infinately easier then being stuck in Pandoran gravity. It brings to mind the low-gravity mutator of Unreal Tournament. Combat additions of cryo-element weapons and lasers are also welcome. I had a lot of fun as Athena the Gladiator, whose elemental tree gives her a hefty punch and whose Aspis denies a huge percentage of incoming damage, giving her incredible survivablity that the entirety of the Borderlands 2 cast lacked- most egregiously Salvador, who in the course of playing I spent an inordinate amount of time as with my face in the dirt waiting to be revived. I had a chance to sample the other characters, including Doppleganger Jack and Aurelia but most notably Wilhelm the Enforcer, whose autonomous drones are a big help in combat. The game is well-written for what it is, though if you are bothered by an excess of memes and references then it will rub you in much the same uncomfortable way that BL2 did. The combat in pre-sequel, I would say, the most refined in the series, and actually feels reasonably balanced, but the level design leaves much to be desired- the mazelike decks of Helios station in particular left me dazed and vexed, and had I not had my friends to guide me I would surely have needed to look at a guide to find my way around. The moon also has its share of navigational difficulties, with twisting, identical-looking crags and instant-death lava pits. For the geographically challenged player like myself, Pre-Sequel can be very annoying, but once you can actually find the battle, you'll have a lot of fun.
