reviewText:
So much negativity out there.

tl;dr: If you haven't played Borderlands 2 and/or cannot appreciate attention to detail, go back to playing CoD or whatever lackluster shooter you wile your life away with.

I loved the hell out of this game. Not so much because it's new and original and different from BL2, because in large part it isn't. In fact, it not being something completely new and original and different from BL2 was part of the hook. As far as gameplay, why fix what isn't broken? And hell, add some lazers and BUTT SLAMS. But as far as the story goes? Anybody who thinks it's lacking wasn't paying attention at some point in their Borderlands career. Likewise, it is NOT something you can just go and read about online if you want to catch the small details and nuances demonstrate how BL2 came to life. It isn't just about how Jack came to power; it's about how Jack stole the reins to Hyperion and flipped EVERYTHING upside down; it's a play-by-play of the deterioration of his humanity; it's a narrative of how his alliances and rivalries were forged; it's a testament to his ingenuity and how he used Hyperion to seize Pandora.

That said, it isn't a game to simply try to breeze through, shooting for the best loot. It's a novelty. A (Re)Making of Pandora" which you get to play a pivotal role in."

reviewText:
It is a decent game. The campaign has a few laughs and the laser guns are a nice addition to the gun types in the series. The oxygen kits are frankly not all that different from the relics though. Some give you weapon damage, others give resistance, some give chance of free grenades. So I wouldn't call it a new feature. The low gravity adds a nice dynamic to the combat, since you now can reach higher places that you wouldn't on Pandora and have to worry about enemies hovering over you which were on ground a moment ago. The characters themselves are good to play with with and their skills are interesting. None of them especially feels overly powerful save for a few combinations and none of them feels weak (cough Axton BL2, cough). The scaling is better than BL2, at least at level 50 (can't tell about it once a level cap increase is released). So, your legendary gear won't go obsolete in 4-5 levels. Good defensive builds are actually viable at level 50, which feels good. The game is overall balanced decently in combat. The player characters also talk more, which is nice if you like more banter (I do). The legendary gear drop rates from enemies are still pretty bad (same as BL2), but the chances of finding legendaries in vendor machines has been increased, so money actually matters in this game if you want good gear and want to buy it when you see it in a machine. The other addition that really makes getting legendaries easier is the grinder, since you don't need to farm for a specific legendary. Just take whatever you got and you canuse the grinder to get a legendary weapon of a desired type (it still leaves some probability since there are many legandaries of a type, say sniper rifles, smgs, pistol etc., but still much better than farming one boss over and over and over).

The main complaint is that the campaign is really short. It feels shorter than BL2 campaign for sure, but it also feels shorter than BL1 campaign. You can complete main questline in 10 hours more or less on normal mode, WITHOUT speed running. Many of the side quests are poorly designed, which require to go to the same area over and over because you are not allowed to unlock all side quests at a place at once, for some reason (it was in BL2 as well, a bit, but here it is really bad). The maps are a bit unintuitive and most of them remind me of frostburn canyon from BL2, which was a bit tricky to memorize. The campaign also has a few plot holes and suffers from poor writing regarding how some of the character behaviors seem very forced.

Overall, I will recommend this game but not at full price. A price of $35-$40 sounds reasonable for a game of this length. And this is a definite buy for Borderlands series fans. So go on kiddos, buy this game (on sale, not full price) and make Jack happy. Learn how Jack turned from a somewhat ♥♥♥♥♥ to a complete psychopath in this game and shoot some bandits (oops, scavs) on the way!

Overall a really great game, especially since it was meant as filler to satisfy fans until Borderlands 3.

reviewText:
It is a decent game. The campaign has a few laughs and the laser guns are a nice addition to the gun types in the series. The oxygen kits are frankly not all that different from the relics though. Some give you weapon damage, others give resistance, some give chance of free grenades. So I wouldn't call it a new feature. The low gravity adds a nice dynamic to the combat, since you now can reach higher places that you wouldn't on Pandora and have to worry about enemies hovering over you which were on ground a moment ago. The characters themselves are good to play with with and their skills are interesting. None of them especially feels overly powerful save for a few combinations and none of them feels weak (cough Axton BL2, cough). The scaling is better than BL2, at least at level 50 (can't tell about it once a level cap increase is released). So, your legendary gear won't go obsolete in 4-5 levels. Good defensive builds are actually viable at level 50, which feels good. The game is overall balanced decently in combat. The player characters also talk more, which is nice if you like more banter (I do). The legendary gear drop rates from enemies are still pretty bad (same as BL2), but the chances of finding legendaries in vendor machines has been increased, so money actually matters in this game if you want good gear and want to buy it when you see it in a machine. The other addition that really makes getting legendaries easier is the grinder, since you don't need to farm for a specific legendary. Just take whatever you got and you canuse the grinder to get a legendary weapon of a desired type (it still leaves some probability since there are many legandaries of a type, say sniper rifles, smgs, pistol etc., but still much better than farming one boss over and over and over).

The main complaint is that the campaign is really short. It feels shorter than BL2 campaign for sure, but it also feels shorter than BL1 campaign. You can complete main questline in 10 hours more or less on normal mode, WITHOUT speed running. Many of the side quests are poorly designed, which require to go to the same area over and over because you are not allowed to unlock all side quests at a place at once, for some reason (it was in BL2 as well, a bit, but here it is really bad). The maps are a bit unintuitive and most of them remind me of frostburn canyon from BL2, which was a bit tricky to memorize. The campaign also has a few plot holes and suffers from poor writing regarding how some of the character behaviors seem very forced.

Overall, I will recommend this game but not at full price. A price of $35-$40 sounds reasonable for a game of this length. And this is a definite buy for Borderlands series fans. So go on kiddos, buy this game (on sale, not full price) and make Jack happy. Learn how Jack turned from a somewhat ♥♥♥♥♥ to a complete psychopath in this game and shoot some bandits (oops, scavs) on the way!

reviewText:
If you like Borderlands 2, This game is for you.
It has some improvement since Borderlands 2, that is, there is no slag.
In previous game, Slag was a elemental effect.
When enemy is under the effect of slag, the damage to that slagged enemy is increased.
It was powerful, that was the problem.

Under the presence of powerful slag, game was balanced for that.
The result, enemy's HP is so high which makes using slag almost mandatory.

Slag was powerful, but using the slag wasn't that fun.
You equip a weak damage but slag weapon just for slagging enemies,
then switch to high damage weapons to finish it off.
Borderlands has only 4 weapon shortcut slot, and switching weapons takes some times makes using slag stressful.

Since there is no slag in TPS, enemy's health is lower than B2.

The only things I don't like in TPS are just 4 weapon slots and switching weapons takes times.

Recommended for Borderlands fans, especially if you can pick it up on sale.

reviewText:
Let me first start off by saying I'm a huge Borderlands fan. I've got well over 100 hours into the first, and over 200 into the second.

So why do I feel conned when I play this one?

After 106 hours, I can safely say that this game starts slow and just never picks up. Thie environments are boring, the enemies are boring, the weapons are boring, the boss fights with the exception of the sentinel are boring. The only thing that's not quite so boring is the grinder, which spews out a legendary every so often. But then again, nearly all of the legendaries with the exception of the laser guns are ripped straight from Borderlands 2 so it just becomes boring again after that little sense of elation wears off when you find something orange.

On top of all this the DLC is all crap too.

I'll start with the character DLC which was graciously included by our 2K overlords in the season pass. Apparently this also affected the quality of both characters. The first was The Doppelganger Jack character who is a man named Timothy and through genetic modification, plastic surgery, and mechanical implants was transformed into a clone of Jack. Pretty solid backstory, but the scaling of this characters Action skill is overpowered. Not to mention there's a bug in Co-operative mode where if you cancel his skill before its halfway expended you'll get the whole thing back. That's right, 2k Austrailia ♥♥♥♥ed up so hard that they made an overpowered action skill and then accidentally made a bug that gave it no cooldown. What stand up gents.

Moving on, the next character is Lady Aurelia the Baroness. This woman is Sir Hammerlock's Sister.

Oh, you expected more? So did I.

This character seems like a quick slap together of something that resembles Mordecai and Claptrap. She's a sniper that has a action skill that flies around near your crosshair and attacks whatevers in the reticle. Sound familiar? Take the first S" off and you have Mordecai. The claptrap part extends to her third tree which is Co-operative only

Onto the map and story dlc.

I'm just gonna compare this to the (quite wonderful) Borderlands 2, which this is otherwise extremely close to - figure out how you feel about that game first, then come back here. :)

Pros:
+ Somewhat better gameplay overall, mostly due to the jumpy/buttslammy stuff.  This is a big plus.
+ Player characters have a lot more character

Cons:
- The writing is a mixed bag, generally neither as funny or intriguing as BL2.  Some real face-palmingly misconceived lines.  But overall entirely adequate.
- Same engine, graphics, physics, menus; nothing technical has improved.
- Everything else about this game, from the level design to the audio, is a notch below BL2.  But that's okay, a notch below BL2 is still high.
- For people expecting to discover Handsome Jack's backstory and rise from zero to antihero: Mostly you don't.  Slightly spoilery details:  At the start of the story he's already a regular ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, he becomes a slightly bigger ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ at random points, and then at the end, bam, some deus ex machina makes him snap the other 90% of the way towards incredible ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ry. reviewText: You've explored enough of Pandora in Borderlands and Borderlands 2, so now, welcome to Elpis, Pandora's moon. Borderlands the Pre-Sequel is the third game in the series, and like its predecessors before it, is equally random and filled with craziness. The plot revolves Handsome Jack and his fall from hero to villain, along with new Vault Hunters that play minor roles in Borderlands 2 (considering the events of the pre-sequel happens before that). The story is engaging enough, and the Vault Hunters have a lot more lines of dialogue during quests, which is a nice addition and breathes more life into your characters. It is also quite amusing that all citizens on Elpis pretty much have an Australian accent, because the Pre-Sequel was developed by 2K Australia. Gameplay is enhanced with the introduction of the Oxygen system in the pre-sequel, considering you are on the moon, and you can now leap into the air and crash down on your foes in a low-gravity atmosphere. This is affectionately called butt-slamming" by the citizens of Elpis. This new Oxygen system also enables you to reach places that you otherwise wouldn't be able to

reviewText:
Fair warning: only get this game if you are a big fan of Borderlands, or if it's on sale. Because otherwise you will be slightly disappointed. For what was supposed to be another main installment in the Borderlands series, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel felt a bit...off. Both plot and combat-wise, it was simply Borderlands 2.5, with some new mechanics thrown in.

The plot centers (again) around Handsome Jack. It starts out strong, sort of mellows out in between, and then ties up a few loose ends when you finish the game. Most of the characters are returning ones, so there's nothing new there. However, I was BEYOND delighted that the Vault Hunters could finally speak and react to certain events. Overall, the Pre-Sequel's story is a good bridge to what I am assuming to be the next big Borderlands game, but it's not the best on its own.

Combat is still relatively the same as Borderlands 2's. The only differences are the additions of laser guns, cryo, oz kits, and double jumps. None of them are particularly game-changing, but I have to admit that butt-slamming is addictive. There's also a certain satisfaction that comes with leaping high into the air and finishing off an enemy before you touch the ground.

I'm giving the Pre-Sequel a 7/10. Took a bit longer for me to find the push to finish the main storyline compared to Borderlands 2, but I had fun while I did.

reviewText:
Short Review:
A decent game with some cool additions from BL2. If you love Borderlands 2 - get it on a sale. If you have never played a Borderlands game get Borderlands 2 (GOTY). This game is for those people who want to know more about the Borderlands continuity. The story is no dissapointment!

Full Review: (BL2 Spoilers are ahead)
Story:
Now, I have started 2 main playthroughs of this game, the first when I first got the game and my second which I have just completed today. The game revolves around a time after the first game and before the second - as the name suggests. The game gets off to a good start with a decent cutscene lining up our 4 main vanilla characters: Nisha, Claptrap, Wilhelm and Athena. We meet Jack who is a low level Hyperion programmer wanting to find a vault which the lost legion (Dahl) wants to keep a secret.

The first mission is pretty decent in engaging us into the game. Then this is where the game gets really bad (for the meantime). Once you land on the moon, you are greeted by a beautiful yet barren landscape of Elpis. Janey Springs - a nearby engineer finds you and ends up asking you to do a few tasks for you until you get to Concordia - the Sanctuary of Elpis. You are met by Moxxi, Lilith, Roland, Earl, Nina (the doctor) and the Meriff. The story then progresses and starts to get a little bit better as time goes on. The next notably bad mission is the AI mission. Oh my is this a shambles. You arrive at this place seeking an AI to control a robot army or something (which was planned to assualt Helios). It becomes so stretched..... Go to this place, fight bandits........ Oh no, they have blown up the bridge....... Try to pour methane into the lava underneath to cool it.... Oh no, the methane has leaked; Go to a pumping station to fix this........ Oh no, the pumping station is not powered; find the power station........... and on and on and on. That I have to say felt like a low point in the story. Luckily, after that grind, things became a bit more interesting. There are a few anti climactic moments which I wont spoil and there are some amazing moments. I think the game really shines when you get off the moon and get back onto Helios.

Helios is really well designed; great colours, design, enemies etc. It was great and this was where missions started to pace a lot better. The ending and transformation of Jack is amazing and we can feel why he turned evil - it was the people around him. We see the Jack at the start who wanted to save lives and the Jack at the end who wants to end lives. Whats also cool is that we also see in the credits scene Wilhelm turning into a machine, Nisha getting Lynchwood and Claptrap getting his memory wiped and finds the BL2 Vault Hunters. That continuity for me was so cool to watch. The story was also good in the respect that it made me appreciate BL2 a bit more. For example: When Jack poisons Wilhelm so that he is actually killable to the vault hunters in BL2. This makes Jack a lot more a barbaric person. He was able to basically kill the person who had gone through so much with him. It just adds to Jack in so many ways and there are more of these little things.

Gameplay:
The core game mechanics are basically the same from BL2. The only differences I guess are O2 kits instead of Relics, Lasers as a new gun type, cryo as an additional element and slag being removed for continuity purposes (slag weaponry was not developed at this time in the Borderlands universe). There is now an oxygen mechanic which ties into the jump boost, slam and vaccum/breathable atmosphere concepts - all of which are new. This has changed gameplay enough to make it feel fresh but not too much as to make it feel not-borderlands. Oh and I think I forgot about low gravity jumping but it is self-explanatory to be fair. You could argue it slows down fights though; where enemies will be floating slowly around.

Also in terms of new creatures, there is not too many new and interesting enemy types and bosses can sometimes feel uninspired.

A lot of guns are borrowed from BL2 but I guess it is fine, there is enough new weapons to keep it fresh.

Graphics and Sound:
Most objects do come from BL2 but are retextured. The moon itself is quite beautiful yet barren, in the first few hours you will just be running around. To be fair, it has about the same level of detail in textures as BL2 with the same art style: I am not complaining!

Soundwise the game is fine, reusing alot of BL2 files. Marcus' vending machines for example use exactly the same clips from BL2. There is one main gripe though in terms of Science - sound does not travel in a vaccuum because there are no particles for it to travel through but whatever, it doesnt really matter. Voice acting is generally poor - for most of the inhabitants of the moon it sounds like the devs, 2K Australia, literally made the voices themselves. Most of the scav voices are horridly cliched, reused and unoriginal - the examples off the top of my head is Deadlift and those two bandit friends you meet in the story. Again this does not apply to all of them. The vault hunters, Moxxi, Jack, Lilith, Janey and all the other returning characters/voice actors are great - infact I enjoyed them quite alot.

Conclusion:
This game is driven by its story and specifically Jack. If you want more story and continuity to the Borderlands universe, get it on sale. If you want to check out Borderlands get Borderlands 2 and if you want more Borderlands 2, get it on sale. This game is good, but bad pacing brings it down in the first few hours. I do not believe this game is worth full price, with Borderlands 2 you will get more content and a more varied environment than in this game. In fact I didnt tell you about my two playthroughs, The first one I never completed, I just could never get past those few hours. The second playthrough, I forced myself to complete the story and I do not regret it, the last few story missions alone sell this game to me. If you disagree please in form me in the comments and we can have a constructive argument. Thanks for reading! (Damn that was long!)

reviewText: I like Borderlands more as a franchise than this game in particular. The style and playstyle are fun and captivating. That being said, this is almost exactly the same game as borderlands 2. WHich if thats what you're looking for it is great, but if you are hoping for something different or changes to features you will be disappointed. The changes are minor yet clunky. The gravity thing is awkward and is not a part of the game when it would be most useful. Lasers replace slag weapons in a way, but still have unique elemental effects. I mainly got this because I lost borderlands 2 and didn't want to rebuy the same game so it works in that regard. I'm hoping the play style will flow better once my steam controller shows up and I can play it on my big ole TV
